text: okay so here in the one that you can see
the crazy contrast behind me the slums
with skyscrapers behind it and really
cute kids below me this skyline changed
very rapidly over the past ten years and
most of the building that you seen
behind me we're not here in 2010 when we
think about expensive cities we think
about Singapore or Zurich or New York or
Oslo but who thinks about Luanda I bet
that half of you have never even heard
of the city before have you
lawanda is the capital of angola
a nation twice the size of Texas in
southwestern Africa
I arrived in Luanda a few days ago and
I've been surprised in a lot of ways but
none more than the absurd prices mmm oh
fish God cuatro $1,000 $2,000
2002 zero zero zero over the last half
decade Luanda has consistently been
ranked at the top of the world's most
expensive cities for expats and tourists
the penthouse in that building behind me
was valued at nine million dollars which
was the most expensive apartment in all
of Africa just head into any supermarket
and look around Grey Goose is a hundred
and five dollars dog food 170 so having
a pet in Angola would not be the
distribution of a light bulb 15 a box of
cereal 12 a MacBook Pro 4200 and this TV
is over ten thousand dollars care to
dine at a nice restaurant make sure to
bring a lot of cash with you okay a 30
minute taxi ride will run you about $80
an average hotel room is north of 200
wanna rent an apartment the cost of a
three-bedroom place of international
standards in a nice area is around
$12,000 per month
my friend pays 80 bucks a month just for
his Wi-Fi bill that's four times what I
pay in Bangkok the reason for all of
this cost madness lies in a three letter
word oil Angola has the second biggest
oil reserve in Africa we are a country
less blessed with several natural
resources oil diamonds this means a very
fast-growing economy whereas the
infrastructure hasn't caught up due to
the civil war which left the country in
shambles upon ending in 2002 Luanda was
built for 500,000 people but now there's
over 8 million the shortage of supply
for housing with a high demand to move
here explains for the expensive prices
so entrenched corruption the need to
import everything and the fact that we
don't produce
thing contributes to the high prices you
see here but what confuses me the most
is how locals can afford to live here
when basic goods are double the cost as
neighboring countries
well actually the local markets are not
as expensive for basic goods but
nonetheless people here are struggling
two-thirds of the population live in
extreme poverty or making less than $2 a
day on the outskirts of Luanda less than
20% of households have electricity and
access to clean water education is
another issue which goes along with the
unemployment rate at over 20 percent
more over the Angolan Kwanza keeps
weakening against the US dollar causing
everyday prices to continue rising
especially anything imported like the
MacBook Pro or the TV as you can see the
economics nerd inside of me is going
nuts right now to analyze the current
situation in Angola
Luanda is such an interesting place and
I cannot wait to see more
I'm drew pinsky and if you like my
travel videos please click Subscribe and
join me as I plan to visit every country
in the world
